Situation1: They notice a few pool chairs are slightly misaligned but still usable.
Expectation2: Observe kosher dietary laws in daily meals
Situation2: While traveling, only a small vendor known to be kosher-certified is within reach for the next meal.
Story: I was finishing my shift as a lifeguard, scanning the pool deck for anything out of place. The sun was dipping low, and I noticed a few pool chairs were slightly misaligned. Technically, they were still usable, but the facility manager always expected everything to be perfectly arranged before closing. I glanced at my watch—if I took the time to fix the chairs, I’d miss my chance to grab dinner at the only kosher vendor nearby, which closed soon. As a Jew, keeping kosher is non-negotiable for me, even when traveling. My stomach rumbled, reminding me I hadn’t eaten since morning. The pressure built inside me: the responsibility to uphold my job’s standards versus my commitment to my faith. I stood there, torn, feeling the weight of both roles pressing in, knowing I had to choose which expectation to meet.
